column2: symbolically taking possession.St. Teresa was designated by traditionalists and the Catholic Church as the "saint of the Spanish race". The Nationalist forces found the remnants of a sculpture of Saint Teresa in Málaga -- one of her hands -- which was sent to Franco. He made a personal cult of devotion to the saint
column3: keeping the relic in his home until he died.

column1: === The Valley of the Fallen ===
This monument to the fallen in the Civil War was built by Republican prisoners of war.
It is a large-scale monument
column2: with the basilica built into the side of a pine-covered mountain and with an enormous stone cross above the entrance.

column1: The stone cross is 500 feet (150 m) high and is visible from a distance of 30 miles (48 km).
The monument and basilica were built in accordance with the Decree of 1 April 1940 providing funds for construction of a basilica
column2: monastery
column3: and youth headquarters in a farm located on the slopes of the Sierra de Guadarrama (El Escorial)
column4: "to perpetuate the memory of the fallen of our glorious Crusade".

column1: Construction began in the 1940s and the structure was completed in 1959.Franco's grave was located beside the altar.
The monument continued to be visited by the dwindling group of his die-hard supporters on the anniversary of Franco's death in the post-Franco era.
José Antonio Primo de Rivera and many other combatants from both sides in the Spanish Civil War are buried in the valley.
Perhaps 50
column2: 000 of Franco's supporters are buried there
column3: along with a handful of Republicans.

column1: Human rights groups have called for El Valle de los Caidos to be converted into a centre that would teach visitors about the Civil War and the Francoist State.
Others have asked that the bodies of Jose Antonio and Franco be removed
and that plaques or other methods be used to give visitors some understanding of the historical background. In 2019
column2: Franco's body was exhumed and his remains were re-buried in a family crypt near Madrid.

column1: === Sacred Heart of Jesus ===
The Cerro de los Ángeles (Hill of the Angels) is the site of the Monumento al Sagrado Corazón (Monument of the Sacred Heart).
The original monument was created by architect Carlos Maura Nadal and sculptor Aniceto Marinas y García
column2: and was inaugurated by King Alfonso XIII on 30 May 1919.

column1: It was destroyed on 7 August 1936 during the civil war. Republicans dynamited the monument due to its religious and political symbolism.
There was a proposal to replace it with a figure representing Liberty or the Republic
column2: but this was not executed.The current monument is similar in design to the 1919 monument
column3: but on a larger scale.

column1: Construction began in 1944 in accordance with designs by the architects Pedro Muguruza and Luis Quijada Martínez.
The monument shows Christ with open arms
column2: inviting all men to come to Him.

column1: The 11.5 metres (38 ft) high statue on a 26 metres (85 ft) pedestal is the work of Aniceto Marinas
column2: and the group of sculptures around the base is by Fernando Cruz Solís.

column1: The monument was opened in 1965. The crypt
column2: which did not exist in the original monument
column3: was opened in 1975.

column1: == Place names ==
=== Towns and villages ===
Today
column2: there are a number of towns that preserve the memory of Franco in their official names. The only one which has the status of a municipality is Llanos del Caudillo
column3: with 726 inhabitants. Many other towns and cities that had similar names for decades
column4: such as El Ferrol del Caudillo (until 1982
column5: in the province of La Coruña)
column6: or Barbate de Franco (until 1998
column8: withdrew references to Franco after the restoration of democracy. Franco wanted to honour generals from the Nationalist side by ascribing their names to various locations
column9: and most still retain these names. Such is the case of San Leonardo de Yagüe
column10: where General Juan Yagüe was born
column12: where General Emilio Mola died in a plane crash during the war.

column1: The case of Numancia de la Sagra (Toledo) is another example; since the Middle Ages
column2: this town was known as Azaña
column3: but during the Civil War this coincided with the first name of the then Spanish Prime Minister
column4: Manuel Azaña
column5: so it was replaced in 1936. The original name
column6: Azaña
column7: means wheel (Arab-Moorish word). The town is now called "Numancia"
column8: after the regiment which captured it
column9: and "Sagra" for the region it belongs to.

column1: === Street names ===
The memory of Franco is still present in the names of the streets
column2: squares and avenues of various towns and cities. There are also streets
column3: avenues and squares in many cities and towns in Spain named for generals of the Civil War and the Nationalist party
column4: such as Mola
column5: Sanjurjo
column6: Moscardó
column7: Yagüe and Millán Astray. Other names from the Franco era were used
column8: such as José Antonio Primo de Rivera

column1: == Removal of symbols ==
See also: Historical Memory Law
In January 1980
column2: the Madrid city council decided to rename twenty downtown streets
column3: returning them to the names they had before 14 April 1931
column4: when the Second Republic was created. The Avenida del Generalísimo thus became the Paseo de la Castellana.

column1: In 1981 the Avenida de José Antonio in Madrid was renamed La Gran Vía. Despite the withdrawal of some of the symbols during the first years of the Transition
column2: some symbols remained more than thirty years after his death.

column1: The Spanish Historical Memory Law
column2: approved by the Congress of Deputies on 31 October 2007
column3: mandated the removal of commemorative plaques
column4: statues and other symbols from public buildings. It also opened the public archives covering the Franco period and facilitated the task of locating and exhuming the graves of victims.

column1: Under the 2007 law introduced by the socialist government of José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero
column2: Falangist symbols had to be removed from public view
column3: and streets and plazas that honoured Franco and his entourage had to be renamed.

column1: The law was criticized by both left-wing and right-wing observers
column2: both for being too lenient or too severe.

column1: A historian said that by focusing on the abuses committed by Franco
column2: the government was presenting the left-wing Republican government in too favourable a light
column3: ignoring the many problems of the feuding socialist
column4: anarchist
column5: communist and separatist groups.In 2010 the department of National Heritage stopped offering tours of Franco's private quarters in the Royal Palace of El Pardo
column6: although tours of the older parts of the palace with "high artistic value" continued. In December 2010
column7: the Valle de los Caidos was reopened
column8: but with tight security systems to prevent vandalism or destruction by militant members of victims' associations.

column1: As of 2011
column2: the government was considering exhuming Franco's body from the Valle de los Caidos and reburying it beside his wife in a municipal cemetery. There were some protests
column3: but many supported the plan to transform the site into a place of reconciliation
column4: with plaques to explain the past. Ramón Jáuregui
column5: the responsible minister
column6: said
column7: "We have dealt with the past little by little. Maybe we're tackling this site a little late
column8: but prudence has been the key to our peaceful transition." In October 2019
column9: Franco was exhumed and moved to a family plot near Madrid.There was much debate regarding symbols that might affect the Church
column10: so an exception was introduced for religious reasons
column11: and an exception made for monuments with particular artistic value. There are some emblematic symbols such as the yoke and arrows on the Casa Sindical (a brick tower facing the Museo del Prado) and the Central Headquarters of the Movimiento
column12: the Alcalá de Madrid which was built in a rationalist style.
